text: It's possible this term is shifting in meaning. The problem is, at the moment using "refutes" (which means "definitively disprove") to mean "rebuts" also grants much more authority to the subject than they deserve.
author: johnmcquaid

text: Maybe the problem with "refutes" is that it sounds like a mashup of "rebuts" and "disputes"
author: johnmcquaid

text: Rebuts or disputes – not refutes

text: How the FAA handled @seattletimes inquiries about flaws in the regulatory approval of the #737MAX8. 1. Don't respond. 2. text: The political editor job involves "producing national content for Sinclair Broadcast Group’s network of news sites" – mainly, local TV news sites. So, is the idea to Foxify these sites beyond the mandatory Boris Epshteyn 2-minutes hate segments?

text: In other words there is a linguistics/sociology/social contagion phenomenon at work that we maybe don't understand that well.

text: It's not surprising, exactly. But I found myself wondering, "why does this guy in Upstate NY hating on Nancy Pelosi on Facebook *sound* exactly like this Twitter troll in Texas talking about guns?"
author: johnmcquaid

text: Re: Krugman https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/11/opinion/captain-marvel-republican-rage.html …. One thing that struck me: the rage is typically expressed in an instantly recognizable, aggrieved, hypermasculine tone. In other words, it always *sounds* the same, despite differences in location, social class, subject, etc.
author: johnmcquaid

text: Those of us born at the end of the Baby Boom are, IMO, in an even worse position. Associated with the awfulness of the cohort that preceded us; too young for the fun part of the 1960s; grew up in the 1970s. And have no cool name.

text: In other words, we see desires (and feelings, thoughts, et al) as part of "the self" but the Buddha taught his followers to systematically label these things as not-that. Not sure where that quote originates but this gives a feel for the method: https://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn22/sn22.059.mend.html …
author: johnmcquaid

text: That means letting go of desires. Not stopping them – you're still human – but not getting caught up in them, letting them mindlessly rule your actions.
author: johnmcquaid

text: A core principle of Buddhism is "no-self" - that what we experience as "I" is really an-ever shifting collection of causes and conditions. The aim of Buddhism is to wake up to this reality (the cessation of self-identification).
author: johnmcquaid
